doc.field: Fischer will not reject possibility of deploying non-NATO troops

The Minister of Foreign Affairs Joschka Fischer, who has been holding talks in the Ukranian capital Kiev, says he is willing to consider the deployment of non-NATO led troops. Fischer stressed that attaching too much importance to form should be avoided.
Schily promises aid to Albanians

More than 6000 refugees from Kosovo have arrived in Germany so far. After a talk with Milo (sp?), the Albanian minister of Foreign Affairs, the German Minister of Internal Affairs Otto Schily, says that the German government will provide shelter for up to 40.000 refugees in Albania.
Kvaerner group will sell shipbuilding companies

The British-Norwegian Kvaerner group is going to withdraw world-wide from the shipbuilding industry and cut approximately 25,000 jobs. A statement to that effect from the company's board of directors in Oslo was confirmed by the Kvaerner shipyard in Warmemuende. Also, terms of sale negotiations for the shipbuilding company in Warmemuende are currently underway. By May 6th, decisions on this matter are expected to have been reached. In any case the shipyard will have a new owner. The approximately 1500 jobs at the shipyard are not in any danger, however.
Eichel dismisses Lafontaine confidants

The new Minister of Finance Hans Eichel, intends to appoint World Bank manager Koch-Weser and tax lawyer Zizelsberger as tenured Secretaries of State. This was confirmed today by the ministry in Bonn. They will replace the present Secretaries of State Flassbeck and Noe, who were known to be in close confidence with Mr. Eichel's predecessor Oskar Lafontaine. Both Parliamentary State Secretaries, Hendriks and Diller, will retain their positions.
Viking-Youth remain banned

The right-extremist Viking Youth remain banned. The Federal Administrative Court in Berlin ruled that the organisation shows close similarities to the Hitler Youth, and members of the organisation have both acted and expressed themselves in an anti-constitutional, racist and anti-semitic manner. With this decision the judges deny the Viking Youth's (founded in 1952) appeal against a banning order imposed by the Ministry of Internal Affairs five years ago.
North Rhine-Westphalia lays complaint against caging of hens

The Federal Administrative Court in Karlsruhe has heard today arguments in proceedings against the caging of hens. The plaintive, the state of North Rhine-Westphalia, is going after more natural conditions that are appropriate for keeping hens. However, at the hearing a federal government representative opposed an isolated German approach. Bonn wants to try and reach a EU-wide regulation. The Federal Administrative Court is expected to reach a decision in a month.
Popular initiative in Berlin against spelling reform

The Berlin State government has allowed that a popular initiative against the spelling reform will take place, as demanded by a Berlin based association. According to the State government spokesman, Mr Butz, the popular initiative will be held between May 10 and July 9. In this period of time, Berlin citizens will be able to sign into certain lists to second the initiative. If at least 243,000 sign such an initiative, a referendum on the spelling reform will be held.
Crashed suspension railway car to be recovered tonight

The local transport authorities of Wuppertal prepare the recovering of the crashed suspension railway car that will be heaved out of the Wupper river around midnight with a 300t crane. Three people had been killed in the accident, and 47 injured, some of them seriously.
4 deaths in crash of military helicopter

A crash of a Bundeswehr (German Armed Forces) helicopter at the Berlin Airport Tegel has caused the death of four soldiers. The Defense ministry in Bonn confirmed the accident. According to a spokesperson, the helicopter crashed while approaching for landing at the military part of the airport, and then caught fire. The reasons for the accident were still unknown. According to the spokesperson, the helicopter was on a training flight.
3 prisoners escaped in Brandenburg
In the state of Brandenburg, three prisoners escaped from jail. The three Rumanians had drilled a hole into the outer wall of the prison Brandenburg- Havel.
Theater at Baden-Baden to get state subsidies

Christian and Liberal Democrats (CDU and FDP) have agreed at separat meetings in Stuttgart to support the financially troubled "Festspielhaus" theater at Baden-Baden with a DM6.5 million state subsidy. Tomorrow the city of Baden- Baden will decided whether they are going to double this subsidy out of city funds.
Ruling against Konstantin Wecker quashed

The case against singer-songwriter Konstantin Wecker for possessing illegal drugs will have to be tried again. The Munich Prosecutor's Office confirmed that the Bavarian Regional High Court set aside the sentence of the Munich Regional Court that had convicted the 51-year old Mr Wecker to 2 1/2 years in prison. According to the Regional High Court, the Munich Regional Court did not consider appropriately whether the artist was at least partially unresponsible.
Another culprit arrested of Aalen hostage drama

In connection with yesterday's hostage drama at Aalen, police arrested a fourth culprit. Warrants of arrests have been issued against the other three culprits [arrested earlier]. According to the Ellwangen Prosecutor's Office, the man arrested today is a 24-year old Turk from Aalen. It was probably him who chose the hostages.
